class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-1 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><div class="mdc-o-content-body mck-u-dropcap">
<p><strong>As the energy transition gathers pace,</strong> decarbonization is a growing priority across sectors. While electrification and renewable energy are likely to play a major role in this process, these levers may have limitations in abating emissions in certain industries. In these hard-to-abate industries, green hydrogen could emerge as a key solution (see sidebar “About green hydrogen”).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This article is a collaborative effort by André Anacleto, <a href="/our-people/bernd-heid">Bernd Heid</a>, <a href="/our-people/david-gonzalez">David González</a>, Javier Ferrer García, <a href="/our-people/maria-joao-ribeirinho">Maria João Ribeirinho</a>, and Maurits Waardenburg, with Ignacio Martínez, Segismundo García, and Ugaitz Bartolomé, representing views from the Industry and Energy Transition Initiative.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Hydrogen can be used as an energy source or as a feedstock in several industries. Today, hydrogen is mainly used as a feedstock in two sectors: refining (for example, crude oil hydrocracking and hydrotreating to produce fuels) and the production of chemicals such as ammonia and methanol. Green hydrogen has the potential to replace grey hydrogen in these sectors and could also be used in the production of synthetic fuels (such as e-methanol or e-ammonia for maritime transport and e-kerosene for aviation), as well as in other sectors such as steelmaking (via H<sub>2</sub>-DRI-EAF), helping to decarbonize industries where electrification is not feasible.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ba492c30-6d14-4e43-87ec-160844f238e9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ba492c30-6d14-4e43-87ec-160844f238e9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The use of hydrogen to produce direct reduced iron (DRI), which is then processed in an electric arc furnace (EAF) to produce steel.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mck-c-inline-module-container SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__bgimg-wrapper__Qj4Dt mck-o-sm-left-span SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper__Dpjw2 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__sidebar-wrapper--istablet__IQ6ii mck-u-screen-only mck-c-module-wrapper" data-layer-region="sidebar"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__epoAm  mck-o-md-center"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons-wrapper__9gB_c"><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons___eQy6"><div data-component="mdc-c-dropdown-menu" class="mdc-c-drop-down"><button data-component="mdc-c-button" aria-label="" type="button" id="floating-ui-1" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--ghost mdc-c-button--size-medium mdc-c-drop-down__rootmenu___yJzvz_990311c" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="menu"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--default___f-hQM_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-md___yi5fA_990311c mck-share2-icon"></span><span>Share</span></button><div Sidebar" type="button" id="button_id" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--ghost mdc-c-button--size-medium SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__toggle-btn__EL8iE" aria-expanded="false" data-layer-event-prefix="UI Item" data-layer-action="click" data-layer-category="sidebar" data-layer-subcategory="open" data-layer-text="open sidebar"><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mdc-c-icon--radial___y3csX_990311c mdc-c-icon--size-xxl___cL3ZT_990311c mck-plus-no-circle-icon"></span></button></div></div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About green hydrogen</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Today, more than 99 percent of the hydrogen produced globally is grey (obtained from natural gas via steam methane reforming [SMR]) or black or brown (produced from coal), all of which produce CO<sub>2</sub> as a by-product.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="27e81b0b-4a02-4051-9c75-20a067fc6e40"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="27e81b0b-4a02-4051-9c75-20a067fc6e40" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Global hydrogen review 2023</em>, International Energy Agency, September 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The renewable alternative to grey hydrogen is green (or renewable, based on EU taxonomy)<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="42dc25d1-a5b9-49c8-9373-12022577ec7a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="42dc25d1-a5b9-49c8-9373-12022577ec7a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Following the RFNBO definition of the First Delegated Act: "As a principle, liquid and gaseous fuels of nonbiological origin which are produced from electricity are considered renewable only when the electricity is renewable. This renewable electricity may be supplied by an installation that is directly connected to the installation (typically an electrolyzer) that produces renewable liquid and gaseous transport fuels of nonbiological origin, or may come directly from the grid."</span></span></span></a></span> hydrogen, which is produced from water by electrolysis using renewable energy sources. In 2022, less than 1 percent of hydrogen was produced via electrolysis globally.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dc7b7bdc-b490-4348-944f-60eed167993d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dc7b7bdc-b490-4348-944f-60eed167993d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Global hydrogen review 2023</em>, September 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> While there are other low-carbon hydrogen production routes, such as blue hydrogen (produced from fossil fuels but including CO<sub>2</sub> capture, utilization, or storage) and white hydrogen (from geological origin), these are not yet mature either.</p>
<p>Compared to other decarbonization vectors, green hydrogen can have lower efficiency than electrification in some uses due to the cumulative energy loss in the production process. Other green gases, such as biomethane, currently have a lower trading cost than green hydrogen, with biomethane trading at €80 to €120 per megawatt hour (MWh) compared to €200 to €220 per MWh for green hydrogen and €25 to €30 per MWh for natural gas.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3ea2bdda-f3bb-44eb-b8fb-8fff33e44a57"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3ea2bdda-f3bb-44eb-b8fb-8fff33e44a57" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Dutch TTF natural gas futures, accessed April 10, 2024; EXX HYDRIX index, European Energy Exchange, accessed March 2024; For more on biomethane, see “<a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-iberian-green-industrial-opportunity-biomethane">The Iberian green industrial opportunity: Biomethane</a>,” McKinsey, August 1, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>However, green hydrogen has several characteristics that make it an attractive decarbonization alternative for some sectors. It does not experience the feedstock constraints that can affect biofuel and biogas production. It has a higher energy density than existing batteries and has the capacity to be stored and to discharge large amounts of energy for long durations. It also has the capacity to provide high-temperature heat when burned and has a higher chemical flexibility than other alternatives.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The European Union has put in place several initiatives to foster the demand of green hydrogen as part of its Fit for 55 package, including the Renewable Energy Directive (RED), FuelEU Maritime, and ReFuelEU Aviation regulations.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e856d05b-3577-47db-ab87-740d7c743519"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e856d05b-3577-47db-ab87-740d7c743519" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Fit for 55,” European Council, April 12, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> These not only impose minimum quotas for renewable fuels in different sectors, but also binding renewable fuels of nonbiological origin (RFNBO) targets.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1cde0aaa-7167-4be9-beb0-4df43c8f9a17"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1cde0aaa-7167-4be9-beb0-4df43c8f9a17" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Renewable fuels of nonbiological origin. Projects using biomethane to produce low-carbon hydrogen via SMR would not comply with the current EU RFNBO definition and quotas set by EU regulation, although this low-carbon hydrogen could be used to comply with<sub></sub>CO<sub>2</sub> reduction targets or lower carbon intensity of produced fuels.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>With its abundant potential to produce cost-effective renewable energy, Spain is well-placed to take a leading role in growing Europe’s nascent hydrogen economy. While several barriers would need to be overcome, the country could leverage its competitive renewables and existing industrial hydrogen demand to lead the transition to green hydrogen in Europe.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--ghost mdc-c-button--size-medium mdc-c-drop-down__rootmenu___yJzvz_990311c" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="menu"><span class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The Iberian Industry and Energy Transition Initiative</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Spain and Portugal’s decarbonization targets to achieve net zero by 2050 will require participation from all sectors and industries. McKinsey set up the Iberian Industry and Energy Transition Initiative to act as a leading think tank and a demand and investment accelerator on the Iberian Peninsula. The main goal of the Initiative is to help Spain and Portugal realize their decarbonization goals while capturing the opportunity to develop new industries and scale existing ones.</p>
<p>The Iberian Industry and Energy Transition Initiative currently comprises more than ten founding members, including leading energy, industrial, and financial organizations. Initiative members attend periodic meetings to discuss key thematic missions around the way forward for energy and industry in Spain and Portugal.</p>
<p>In the first quarter of 2024, over 20 roundtables were held to discuss the topics of electrification and renewables, as well as renewable molecules (including green hydrogen, sustainable fuels, and biomethane). The insights from these roundtables helped to inform this article series, which focuses on Spain, though many of the insights can be applied to Portugal as well. A variety of stakeholders will be involved in the effort; public-private collaboration will be essential to materialize the Initiative’s vision.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>In this article—the fourth in our series looking at the Iberian green industrial opportunity—we draw on insights from McKinsey research and members of our Industry and Energy Transition Initiative (see sidebar “The Industry and Energy Transition Initiative”) to explore how Spain can take advantage of its green hydrogen potential to achieve decarbonization, while also creating significant value.</p>
<p>Here we discuss how Spain is in a favorable position to become a major green hydrogen producer in the European Union due to its natural and technical endowments, which create a unique window of opportunity for green hydrogen development. Spain’s ambition of 11.0 gigawatts (GW) of installed electrolyzer capacity by 2030 could translate into the annual production of around 1.1 megatons of green hydrogen, requiring a total investment of about €20,000 million for the electrolyzers alone, with additional investment required for renewable energy.</p>
<p>However, green hydrogen faces several challenges that would need to be addressed for Spain to realize its ambitions. Recent cost increases and limited commitment shown so far from potential offtakers have reduced the speed at which green hydrogen is being developed in Spain compared to expectations.</p>
<p>In this article, we highlight how demand for green hydrogen could be attracted through public–private partnerships and mechanisms to foster and underpin offtake agreements. Production could be accelerated by supporting large-scale green hydrogen production projects to demonstrate technology at scale. Planning grid capacity upgrades in line with advancement of green hydrogen projects would also be a key unlock.</p>
<p>Public stakeholders could facilitate green hydrogen development by defining RFNBO quota quota penalties under the EU Renewable Energy Directive (RED) III, streamlining renewable energy source permits or creating an RFNBO credit market. The availability of soft loans and guarantees offered by public institutions (such as multilateral development banks and export credit agencies) may be fundamental to improving bankability and kick-start large green hydrogen projects. It would also be critical to find the most efficient distribution of public incentives both at the EU and Spanish levels.</p>
<h2>Spain’s green hydrogen potential</h2>
<p>Spain currently produces around 0.6 megatons per annum (Mtpa) of hydrogen, all of it grey, which accounts for around 8 percent of the European Union’s total hydrogen production.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0ca36218-d209-49b4-8a93-bbd8ee377efa"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0ca36218-d209-49b4-8a93-bbd8ee377efa" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Clean hydrogen monitor 2023</em>, Hydrogen Europe, November 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>However, Spain is well-placed to become a leader in green hydrogen production. A ready supply of cost-effective renewable energy is a crucial component in producing green hydrogen, and Spain has the potential to produce abundant, low-cost renewable energy, thanks to its unique natural and technical endowments.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="18f9e6d9-82c3-4a5a-bc9f-ab20b4795ef5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="18f9e6d9-82c3-4a5a-bc9f-ab20b4795ef5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more, see “<a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-iberian-green-industrial-opportunity-green-hydrogen">The Iberian green industrial opportunity: Seizing the moment</a>,” McKinsey, July 30, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Spain has around 300 sunny days per year, resulting in a levelized cost of energy (LCOE) for solar that is approximately 40 to 50 percent lower than the EU average. Although LCOE does not directly translate into levelized cost of hydrogen (LCOH),<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="003e4cfc-6245-4113-95f6-dc6d41fc3939"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="003e4cfc-6245-4113-95f6-dc6d41fc3939" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For cost calculations, we used PPA prices as the baseline, as described later in this article.</span></span></span></a></span> a lower cost of electricity is key to cost-competitive hydrogen production. Furthermore, Spain has one of the world’s most mature power purchase agreement (PPA) markets. Thanks to all these factors, green hydrogen could be produced for €4.0 to €5.5 per kilogram in Spain by 2030, around 10 to 20 percent below the projected production cost in Central Europe.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4e5fb9f7-6242-4b1c-9ca9-919d8a3a7613"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4e5fb9f7-6242-4b1c-9ca9-919d8a3a7613" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Assuming no incentives, the same capital expenditure, operating expenditure, and financial cost, and a difference in the cost of electricity proportional to the difference in estimated LCOEs between Spain and Germany of 40 percent.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Additionally, Spanish demand dynamics are already strong, with around 0.6 Mtpa of hydrogen consumed in 2023. Refining currently accounts for around three-quarters of the Spanish hydrogen demand, with chemicals production accounting for the remaining quarter. Within chemicals, ammonia production for fertilizers accounts for 60 percent of hydrogen demand, while methanol and other chemicals represent around 40 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6c669535-6ab4-4dea-91dd-e1457acbf67f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6c669535-6ab4-4dea-91dd-e1457acbf67f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Clean hydrogen monitor 2023</em>, November 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> These sectors currently largely consume grey hydrogen but could switch to green hydrogen as production ramps up. Spain also has a well-established industrial and transport footprint with the potential to drive new hydrogen and synthetic fuels demand in applications where electrification is not feasible or efficient.</p>
<p>Hydrogen-based fuel production requires large amounts of CO<sub>2</sub>, and Spain (together with Portugal) is the fifth largest emitter of biogenic CO<sub>2</sub> in the European Union due to its large pulp and paper industry and bioenergy power plants. Spain currently emits approximately 9.0 Mtpa of biogenic CO<sub>2</sub>, which, if captured, would be sufficient to cover the expected CO<sub>2</sub> demand coming from synthetic fuel production by 2030 (0.6 Mtpa CO<sub>2</sub>) or even 2040 (3.6 Mtpa CO<sub>2</sub>). This, combined with an abundance of low-price renewable energy, positions Spain as a potential synthetic fuel powerhouse with the ability to supply other synthetic fuel-demanding countries that don’t have access to large amounts of biogenic CO<sub>2</sub> or competitive renewables.</p>
<p>Regarding the transport of hydrogen, Spain has the potential to retrofit its existing network of gas pipelines for the transportation of green hydrogen, both for domestic consumption and for export. Additionally, Spain enjoys an advantageous geographical position for maritime trading routes. Its large liquefied natural gas (LNG) regasification terminals, if retrofitted, could be leveraged to export hydrogen and its derivatives.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="636a990c-33ba-48c5-b095-6e4fa48fc84a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="636a990c-33ba-48c5-b095-6e4fa48fc84a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Ana Maria Jaller-Makarewicz, “European LNG tracker,” Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis, February 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Together, these factors put Spain in a strong position to become a leader in green hydrogen production in Europe. However, the country must act fast to take advantage of this window of opportunity, as other regions, such as Germany, Sweden, and the United States, are already competing to fill the green hydrogen space.</p>
<h3>Spain could install 15 to 20 percent of the total EU electrolyzer capacity target by 2030</h3>
<p>The European Union aims to increase green hydrogen consumption to 20 Mtpa by 2030, with half produced domestically and the rest imported from countries outside the region.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0f2dd0bb-9456-4899-88db-7f003604ded6"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0f2dd0bb-9456-4899-88db-7f003604ded6" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“EU hydrogen strategy,” European Commission, accessed August 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> To meet this domestic production target, member states would need to reach 65 GW of installed electrolyzer capacity, based on EU estimates. However, the necessary total installed electrolyzer capacity could be higher depending on the actual electrolyzer utilization and efficiency.</p>
<p>In an aspirational scenario based on the targets laid out in the nonbinding National Integrated Energy and Climate Plan 2021–2030 (PNIEC), Spain could install 11 GW of electrolyzer capacity by 2030, reaching 15 to 20 percent of the total EU target and producing around 1.1 Mtpa of green hydrogen (Exhibit 1).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="21953be7-8ee8-4ab7-8050-c608b4c0f3f1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="21953be7-8ee8-4ab7-8050-c608b4c0f3f1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>National integrated energy and climate plan 2021–2030 (PNIEC)</em>, Spanish Ministry for the Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> In September 2024, the Spanish government published an updated target of 12 GW of electrolyzer capacity by 2030 in Boletin Oficial del Estado (BOE).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="afe7df21-ec22-4df1-951b-f17419eef04b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="afe7df21-ec22-4df1-951b-f17419eef04b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Ministry for the ecological transition and the demographic challenge,” Official State Bulletin, September 23, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> However, in the analyses included in this paper, we will refer to the previous target of 11 GW when referring to PNIEC.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/the%20iberian%20green%20industrial%20opportunity%20green%20hydrogen/svgz-spain-and-portugal-chapter3_ex1-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Spain has the potential to increase its hydrogen production by around 2.5 times by 2030, with most of the increase coming from green hydrogen." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/the%20iberian%20green%20industrial%20opportunity%20green%20hydrogen/svgz-spain-and-portugal-chapter3_ex1-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>In a scenario based on the fulfillment of policies currently in place and the existing market trajectory, there is a high risk of not meeting the PNIEC’s targets, as Spain would only reach a total installed electrolyzer capacity of 5 to 6 GW by 2030. Although the total announced electrolyzer capacity for green hydrogen projects in Spain until 2030 is higher than 11 GW (more than 20 GW have been announced to be operational by 2030), our analysis shows that more than 95 percent of those announcements are still in feasibility and pre-front-end engineering design (FEED) stages, and only a fraction are likely to pass final investment decision (FID) to be operational by 2030.</p>
<p>Public funding targeting investments into green hydrogen production is already being mobilized in the European Union and within Spain. For example, through the National Recovery and Resilience Plan, Spain has already allocated around €490 million to 77 renewables, hydrogen, and storage projects.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c452d47d-73cf-4998-853b-2b8867d5f4c5"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c452d47d-73cf-4998-853b-2b8867d5f4c5" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“PERTE for renewable energy, renewable hydrogen and storage,” Spanish Government, Recovery plan, transformation, and resilience, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> However, most of those incentives have not been disbursed yet, and around €2,660 million of the total funds available remains unallocated as of April 2024. The European Union has also recently approved a Spanish program of €1,200 million aiming to support green hydrogen production projects, targeting projects of more than 100 MW of installed electrolyzer capacity under the condition that at least 60 percent of the expected hydrogen to be produced is secured under an offtake agreement.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="88e54567-4b3d-487a-9f77-38819daec17d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="88e54567-4b3d-487a-9f77-38819daec17d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Eduardo González, “Brussels approves 1.2 billion to support renewable hydrogen production in Spain,” <em>Diplomat</em>, July 28, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Increasing the speed and agility with which this funding is assigned and disbursed would help support green hydrogen developers and ensure that the European Union’s and Spain’s ambitious green hydrogen targets are met.</p>
<h2>Key challenges and unlocks for Spain’s 2030 aspirations</h2>
<p>For Spain to be able to fulfill its potential for green hydrogen production and demand, barriers may need to be overcome in five key areas: fostering demand for green hydrogen and derivatives; scaling up green hydrogen production and ensuring its competitiveness; navigating EU and Spanish regulations on green hydrogen; financing first-of-a-kind green hydrogen projects and making them bankable; and deploying the infrastructure needed to develop green hydrogen production, transport, and storage.</p>
<p>Each of these is examined below, along with identified unlocks that could help Spain become a leader in green hydrogen and achieve its aspirational targets.</p>
<h3>1. Fostering demand for green hydrogen and derivatives</h3>
<p>Since regulatory green hydrogen quotas are met at the point of consumption, not production, of hydrogen, both production and consumption would need to occur within the country for Spain to reap the full benefit of the green hydrogen ecosystem.</p>
<p>As such, demand for hydrogen and derivatives would need to grow, both through existing uses switching from grey to green hydrogen and through new applications. In the aspirational scenario, Spanish green hydrogen production would fully meet internal demand, with only around 20 percent of the green hydrogen produced by 2030 exported to other EU countries.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="cfec9c5b-f056-4674-8999-cfa73935eee2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="cfec9c5b-f056-4674-8999-cfa73935eee2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In the short term, these exports would be in the form of derivatives such as ammonia and synthetic kerosene rather than hydrogen molecules, and these would be used primarily as end products rather than being reconverted to hydrogen (for example, green ammonia for fertilizer production).</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Production targets would fully meet regulatory demand set by the green hydrogen quotas established by the European Union. RFNBO quotas set under RED III<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9b2ec164-39e6-4d24-a8fc-c1c501d69238"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9b2ec164-39e6-4d24-a8fc-c1c501d69238" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Renewable Energy Directive,” European Commission, November 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> in existing industries (such as refining and chemicals), as well as those set in FuelEU and ReFuelEU in sectors where hydrogen is not yet being used (such as transportation), would result in around 0.5 Mtpa of regulation-driven green hydrogen demand by 2030 in Spain. This would be split into approximately 0.3 Mtpa of “regulatory demand,” referring to demand directly coming from the application of a RFNBO subquota (for example, a quota of 1.2 percent RFNBOs in aviation set by ReFuelEU), and 0.2 Mtpa of “incentivized demand,” referring to the demand for green hydrogen that can be used to fulfill other regulatory targets that are not specifically RFNBO subquotas (for instance, the quota of 5.5 percent advanced biofuels and RFNBOs set in RED III).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="00660633-3789-4171-beb6-f41f475a09ac"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="00660633-3789-4171-beb6-f41f475a09ac" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For more details on this split between regulatory and incentivized demand, see section 3, “Navigating EU and Spanish regulation on green hydrogen.”</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Including this regulatory demand, our analysis suggests that Spain has the potential to increase its internal demand for green hydrogen to around 0.9 Mtpa by 2030, leveraging both traditional hydrogen-consuming sectors, such as refining and chemicals, and new sectors that could be decarbonized through hydrogen, such as steel, maritime, and aviation (Exhibit 2).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/the%20iberian%20green%20industrial%20opportunity%20green%20hydrogen/svgz-spain-and-portugal-chapter3_ex2-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Besides traditional uses, new uses like steel, maritime, and aviation could drive green hydrogen demand in Spain by 2030." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/the%20iberian%20green%20industrial%20opportunity%20green%20hydrogen/svgz-spain-and-portugal-chapter3_ex2-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Hydrogen-consuming industries (refining and chemicals) switching from grey to green hydrogen would account for around 50 percent of the aspirational demand by 2030, mainly driven by RED III quotas. Additionally, rising CO<sub>2</sub> costs (driven by the expansion of the EU Emissions Trading System, the implementation of the European Union’s Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism, and the phasing out CO<sub>2</sub> allowances), along with potential green premiums, would also drive green hydrogen demand in new applications such as green steel, maritime, and aviation. However, current production technologies would require extensive retrofitting and additional time and investments.</p>
<p>Other potential applications, including road transport (mainly fuel cell electric vehicles for heavy-duty trucks or buses) and blending with natural gas for commercial and residential buildings,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ee13a5fc-27cb-45f4-be9a-2235cd4aab69"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ee13a5fc-27cb-45f4-be9a-2235cd4aab69" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In the case of blending hydrogen with natural gas for buildings, the International Energy Agency estimates that a blending rate of 20 percent of green hydrogen would only reduce the CO<sub>2</sub> emissions associated with heating and cooling buildings by 7 percent; <em>Global hydrogen review 2021</em>, International Energy Agency, October 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> could also increase the demand for green hydrogen but at a smaller scale, since these sectors are not subject to specific RFNBO targets or there are alternative decarbonization technologies that can be more cost-competitive, such as electrification, biofuels, or biomethane.</p>
<h4>Challenges and unlocks</h4>
<p><strong>Offtake agreements:</strong> The projected reduction in green hydrogen production costs over time could reduce the willingness to commit to long-term offtake agreements, which increases the uncertainty of the viability of green hydrogen production plants today and reduces their bankability.</p>
<p>This could be offset by providing public guarantees for green hydrogen offtake agreements. This would help reduce uncertainty of demand, especially in the long term, increasing viability and bankability. For example, in Spain, the CESCE/FERGEI fund provides a similar mechanism for PPAs.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3a7e4951-5524-4372-acc3-447d4c0449ba"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3a7e4951-5524-4372-acc3-447d4c0449ba" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Credit risk coverage program for electro-intensive consumers,” CESCE, accessed May 24, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> Additionally, it would be important to ensure offtake credibility through partnerships between players along the value chain. Players with “skin in the game” (both equity and offtake agreements) would increase creditworthiness and facilitate bankability of the projects. This strategy has been used in H2 Green Steel’s project in Sweden, where 13 equity sponsors, including offtakers, collectively raised €2,100 million.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e3d2ee4a-de0b-42c5-939d-dd9d341aad7a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e3d2ee4a-de0b-42c5-939d-dd9d341aad7a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“H2 Green Steel raises more than €4 billion in debt financing for the world’s first large-scale green steel plant,” H2 Green Steel, January 22, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p><strong>Hydrogen-demanding industries:</strong> Low prices of grey alternatives, such as natural gas direct reduced iron (NG-DRI) for low-carbon steel production could impose obstacles for industrial players to rapidly switch to green hydrogen. New technologies would also need to be put in place to adapt to green hydrogen.</p>
<p>The cost-competitiveness of synthetic kerosene compared to other sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) alternatives in aviation, or the uncertainty around the winning maritime low-carbon fuels, can also make it difficult for organizations in these sectors to back the transition to specific synthetic fuels. Additionally, the limited port refueling infrastructure for methanol and ammonia, as well as the lack of hydrogen refueling stations in road corridors, could prevent private players committing to the transition to hydrogen and hydrogen-derived fuels.</p>
<p>Creating an appealing regulatory, fiscal, and financial environment could help attract hydrogen-consuming industries (for example, steel manufacturers or fertilizer producers). This could incentivize potential green hydrogen offtakers to develop new greenfield capacity in Spain, reindustrializing the country and ensuring future demand for green hydrogen. For example, the US Inflation Reduction Act (IRA) incentivizes foreign players to build their new manufacturing capacity in the United States.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="71666a35-6472-410c-b0c3-6adb8df88611"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="71666a35-6472-410c-b0c3-6adb8df88611" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Leigh Collins, “US awards about $335m of investment tax credits for new hydrogen-equipment manufacturing facilities,” Hydrogen Insight, April 19, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>A complementary strategy could be the international promotion of Iberian endowments for green hydrogen and derivatives production, with trade missions and investment programs for renewable energies. These initiatives would also attract foreign capital in green hydrogen production projects to the country.</p>
<p>Finally, public incentives could also be deployed for hydrogen downstream technologies, such as the Fischer-Tropsch process or methanol synthesis, to incentivize specific demand segments.</p>
<p><strong>Green premiums:</strong> Increasing visibility on green premiums for green hydrogen-based products would help to reduce uncertainty around future cash flows and improve the economic viability of green hydrogen production projects. For example, for green steel, some offtakers, including automotive OEMs and high-end real estate developers, are starting to signal their willingness to pay premiums ranging from €100 to €300 per ton of green steel.</p>
<h3>2. Scaling up green hydrogen production and ensuring its competitiveness</h3>
<p>In Spain, existing green hydrogen production projects mostly range from 1 to 10 MW of electrolyzer capacity, with the largest operational project as of April 2024 having an installed capacity of 20 MW (Iberdrola’s plant in Puertollano).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1a9efed5-2c38-4f12-b1e3-0dfc88f27755"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">22</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1a9efed5-2c38-4f12-b1e3-0dfc88f27755" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Puertollano green hydrogen plant: Iberdrola installs the largest green hydrogen plant for industrial use in Europe,” Iberdrola, May 24, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> To reach the country’s targets, hundreds of megawatt- and even gigawatt-scale projects would need to be operational by 2030, and the average size of electrolyzers would need to grow 100- to 200-fold. This would require proving and choosing the optimal electrolyzer technology to operate at scale, considering electrolyzer efficiency, intermittency of renewable energy sources (RES), and required firmness for hydrogen derivatives production (offtakers).</p>
<p>More developed green hydrogen supply chains and larger electrolyzer manufacturing plants would also be needed. In 2023, the European Union had 3.9 GW per year of electrolyzer manufacturing capacity (with no large-scale<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="95a0bf88-51e9-4e91-9780-5e43e07d3884"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">23</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="95a0bf88-51e9-4e91-9780-5e43e07d3884" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">More than 100 MW.</span></span></span></a></span> electrolyzer manufacturing capacity in Spain). Based on announcements from OEMs, this would increase to 21 GW per year in 2025 and 25 GW per year in 2030, which would be sufficient to meet the target for installed electrolyzer capacity for 2030.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="79ee0bd9-7b62-4e25-bb51-2bf275c958a3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">24</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="79ee0bd9-7b62-4e25-bb51-2bf275c958a3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“European Clean Hydrogen Alliance,” European Commission, 2020; “Electrolyser summit—State of play,” European Commission, June 22, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> However, some of the expansions may not materialize as we see orders and FID get delayed.</p>
<p>It would also be important to ensure the availability of the necessary feedstocks (renewable electricity and water) for these large-scale projects, along with access to crucial materials (including platinum group metals and iridium) and critical components, such as transformers and rectifiers.</p>
<p>For it to scale up, green hydrogen production would need to be cost-competitive. However, cost projections for green hydrogen have increased over the last few years, mainly due to increases in capital expenditure (capex), electricity prices, inflation, and interest rates. This, combined with the expected normalization of natural gas prices as new production capacity comes online in the years ahead, could increase the gap between willingness to pay and LCOH in the short term (Exhibit 3).</p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>LCOH sensitivity analysis</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Changes in different variables, including electrolyzer efficiency, electricity cost, plant and electrolyzer capex, utilization, and cost of equity, would impact the LCOH to different extents (exhibit).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit </span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/the%20iberian%20green%20industrial%20opportunity%20green%20hydrogen/svgz-spain-and-portugal-chapter3_exsidebar-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Five variables were analyzed to determine their isolated impact on the levelized cost of hydrogen." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/the%20iberian%20green%20industrial%20opportunity%20green%20hydrogen/svgz-spain-and-portugal-chapter3_exsidebar-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The two variables with the greatest positive impact on the LCOH (reducing the cost) are those with a direct impact on the total cost of electricity (electrolyzer efficiency and electricity cost), which accounts for 50 to 60 percent of the LCOH. Increasing electrolyzer efficiency from current levels of around 65 percent (associated with the more mature alkaline and proton exchange membrane [PEM] technologies) to 80 percent (similar to the levels announced for state-of-the-art solid oxide electrolyzer cells [SOEC]) could reduce the LCOH by up to €0.8 per kilogram (15 to 20 percent of the LCOH). Similarly, changes in electricity cost also have a relatively large impact on the LCOH. Being able to secure PPAs at low prices would be key to producing hydrogen at a competitive cost, and Spain could benefit from its natural endowments in this regard. Additionally, grid access fees also play a critical role in the total electricity cost, with current fees in Spain around €10 to €15 per MWh for industries like green hydrogen production.</p>
<p>Another large contribution to reducing the LCOH could come from achieving projected capex reductions once the market matures and engineering, procurement, and construction companies (EPCs) and OEMs gain the necessary experience and economies of scale. A reduction of 25 to 30 percent in capex could reduce the LCOH by €0.5 to €0.6 per kilogram (10 to 15 percent of the LCOH). Electrolyzer utilization can also have a large impact on the LCOH, especially when reducing utilization below 50 percent. However, utilization is directly linked to RES configuration, which would change electricity costs<span> </span><span>at the same time and in the opposite direction. Last, although financial cost can impact the LCOH, the contribution of changes in cost of equity would have limited impact compared to other variables considering a project finance structure with a 75 percent leverage ratio. The impact of the cost of equity could be higher for smaller projects where sponsors provide most capital as equity.</span></p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>By 2030, the LCOH in Spain could be around €4.0 to €5.5 per kilogram of hydrogen, with the cost of electricity as its largest contributor. Grid access fees also play a role in the total electricity cost, with current fees in Spain around €10 to €15 per MWh for industries such as green hydrogen. Regulatory requirements could also significantly impact the LCOH and the future development of green hydrogen in Europe. Finally, the LCOH will decline as electrolyzer efficiency increases and technology development and capex reductions materialize, as the market matures. Several variables could affect the LCOH to different extents (see sidebar “LCOH sensitivity analysis”).</p>
<p>Ensuring low electricity prices, achieving economies of scale, gaining clarity on potential green premiums (besides the price of CO<sub>2</sub>), and defining penalties for noncompliance with regulatory RFNBO quotas would all be key to bridge the gap between willingness-to-pay and LCOH in the short term.</p>
<h4>Challenges and unlocks</h4>
<p><strong>Cost-competitiveness:</strong> Economies of scale and the technological development of electrolyzers are both happening slower than anticipated, increasing the projected capex curve. There is also a limited number of top-tier electrolyzer OEMs and EPCs<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4d0e69b9-fc8d-4a22-8e9f-e4332b9ac662"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">25</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4d0e69b9-fc8d-4a22-8e9f-e4332b9ac662" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Engineering, procurement, and construction companies.</span></span></span></a></span> capable of building large-scale green hydrogen production plants, which increases prices and reduces the bargaining power of green hydrogen developers. To offset this, companies could pool electrolyzer demand to achieve better prices through economies of scale, such as Air Products, which in 2020 ordered 2 GW of electrolyzers from Tyssenkrupp-Nucera to be delivered in batches over a six-year period.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e87662f8-5a8c-4a44-8245-efd4e2a5eb8a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">26</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e87662f8-5a8c-4a44-8245-efd4e2a5eb8a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Air Products and thyssenkrupp sign exclusive strategic cooperation agreement for world-scale electrolysis plants to generate green hydrogen,” Air Products, May 7, 2020; McKinsey analysis.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>For operating expenditure (opex), although electricity prices are projected to fall as RES becomes a larger part of the energy mix, there is still uncertainty around the magnitude of the reduction, especially given the recent impact of geopolitical events on the European Union’s energy markets. On top of that, grid connection fees could represent 10 to 25 percent of total green hydrogen production costs by 2030 in Spain.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6ad02c72-b78c-4962-a628-bf7c22409593"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">27</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6ad02c72-b78c-4962-a628-bf7c22409593" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey analysis.</span></span></span></a></span> Additionally, high inflation over the last two years has increased labor and material costs, resulting in an increase in the total production cost for green hydrogen.</p>
<p>The barriers around opex could be tackled in two ways. Electricity prices could be reduced through partnerships between RES and hydrogen developers, achieving electricity prices closer to the levelized cost of energy (LCOE). For example, Lhyfe and EDPR signed a 15-year partnership to produce green hydrogen in Germany.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e7465f86-557d-497e-830f-7bf985ba9fcc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">28</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e7465f86-557d-497e-830f-7bf985ba9fcc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“EDPR chosen by Lhyfe to supply clean energy in a long-term contract in Germany,” EDP Renewables, January 24, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> The LCOH could also be reduced by optimizing RES configuration for electrolyzer utilization. Based on green hydrogen output requirements, developers could optimize the configuration of RES (solar, wind, and potentially batteries) together with electrolyzer and hydrogen storage size to reduce the overall green hydrogen production cost and ensure optimal utilization. For example, under certain circumstances, it might be optimal to combine and oversize solar and wind generation capacity to around two to three times combined the installed electrolyzer capacity<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fd43cc2f-8ad0-43bb-ac4b-737f652a74c2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">29</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fd43cc2f-8ad0-43bb-ac4b-737f652a74c2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Optimal RES and electrolyzer configuration will depend on the site location of RES.</span></span></span></a></span> to help green hydrogen producers achieve electrolyzer utilizations above 50 percent while reducing LCOH.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6931771d-f565-47a5-b190-1515fa938ca3"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">30</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6931771d-f565-47a5-b190-1515fa938ca3" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Hydrogen Insights LCOH optimization tool.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>An option for countries such as Spain and Portugal that benefit from abundant cost-competitive RES, is to connect to the grid and produce green hydrogen intermittently when RES generation is high and day-ahead electricity prices are below the threshold of €20 per MWh or 36 percent of the EU ETS carbon allowance price defined by EU regulation. This is becoming more frequent as RES penetration increases, with electricity prices in certain periods of the day falling to near zero. This would allow green hydrogen producers to connect their electrolyzers directly to the grid, without PPAs, and get the full green hydrogen credentials for their production during those hours. In a country like Spain, this strategy could reduce LCOH by approximately €0.5 per kilogram in 2030, achieving LCOH levels around €4.0 per kilogram with utilizations of 35 to 40 percent. However, these results are highly dependent on RES deployment and intermittent generation, which increase uncertainty and would make it difficult for green hydrogen producers to secure an offtake agreement with a player that requires certain firmness levels.</p>
