class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>Other potential revenue streams</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Some green hydrogen producers could seek additional revenue streams. Although these will not be available for all of them, the additional revenue streams could help some projects improve their economic viability. These could include:</p>
<ul>
    <li><strong>Optimal direct RES and grid connection mix:</strong> One option is to leverage new RES in combination with connection to the grid. By doing this, hydrogen producers could sell green hydrogen according to the percentage of renewable electricity used (both from direct RES and grid with PPA) and sell the rest as low-carbon or grey hydrogen (depending on the emission intensity of the electricity used from the grid). In fact, several Spanish projects are currently considering this strategy for hydrogen derivatives (for example, producing RFNBO, low carbon, and “grey electrolytic” ammonia under the same facility connected to the grid).</li>
    <li><strong>Grid balancing compensation mechanisms:</strong> Another option would be to incorporate the electrolyzers into the “active response to demand service,” which allows the transmission system operator (TSO) to order mandatory stops of operations to balance the grid. In exchange, green hydrogen producers would receive a fixed fee for making themselves available for the service, and extra variable fees for those hours they are asked to stop. This mechanism could constitute an extra revenue source for those few projects that manage to secure some capacity in the bidding process.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9b6828ad-920d-446d-b2af-9db7f36435b9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9b6828ad-920d-446d-b2af-9db7f36435b9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For the 2023 auction of the Spanish grid, a total capacity of 497 MW was awarded to be available for 2,714 hours. The average fixed price paid was €70 per MW and per available hour. This year, the service was only used for three hours, paying an additional variable price of €133 per MW and stopped hour. For the 2024 auction, a total capacity of 609 MW was awarded to be available for 5,745 hours. The average fixed price paid was €41 per MW and per available hour.</span></span></span></a></span> Due to higher RES penetration increasing intermittency of the power grid, an increased necessity for grid demand adjustment capacity is expected in the coming years. However, it is important to note that as the number of bidders for this mechanism increases, prices for these services would go down, reducing the potential revenue.</li>
    <li><strong>Commercialization of by-product oxygen:</strong> Another possibility some players have explored, such as Everfuel’s facility in Denmark, is to sell the oxygen produced during electrolysis (around eight kilograms of oxygen are produced for every kilogram of hydrogen) to be used for oxy-fuel combustions or as feedstock in industry.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7119dcd7-5204-4f15-b08b-aa7a8a965df9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7119dcd7-5204-4f15-b08b-aa7a8a965df9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Leih Collins, “Additional revenue stream—Byproduct oxygen from 300MW green hydrogen project sold in long-term deal,” Hydrogen Insight, January 3, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> The existing oxygen market is small and balanced, therefore the introduction of large quantities of by-product oxygen could cause an oversupply shock and a sudden price decrease, making this revenue stream less appealing. However, new uses of oxygen might become relevant to increase efficiency of metals and cement furnaces by displacing nitrogen during combustion in a process known as oxy-fuel combustion, increasing the demand for this gas. Other uses include wastewater treatment and pulp and paper production, among others.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Another challenge around cost-competitiveness is the low number of offtake agreements, with less than 10 percent of the announced projects in Spain having publicly announced a signed offtake agreement.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="572e581e-cfc5-429b-bda3-5c1bc78c5234"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">31</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="572e581e-cfc5-429b-bda3-5c1bc78c5234" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">McKinsey Hydrogen Insights project tracker.</span></span></span></a></span> This raises the risk profile of projects, increasing risk premiums. A lack of technological maturity for large-scale electrolyzers also increases the risk premium, and thus the cost of financing large-scale green hydrogen projects. However, in certain cases, green hydrogen producers could unlock additional revenue streams (see sidebar “Other potential revenue streams”).</p>
<p><strong>Scaling up green hydrogen production:</strong> The availability of different electrolyzer technologies (for example, alkaline, proton exchange membrane [PEM], and solid oxide electrolyzer cell [SOEC]) can generate uncertainty around which the optimal choice at scale is, and create hesitancy among green hydrogen developers, with over 50 percent of the projects post-FID not having announced an electrolyzer technology yet.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5513cb77-c2ad-485f-af24-188fbb264fb0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">32</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5513cb77-c2ad-485f-af24-188fbb264fb0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Hydrogen insights 2023</em>, a joint report from McKinsey and the Hydrogen Council, May 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p><strong>Green hydrogen supply chain:</strong> There is a limited number of top-tier electrolyzer OEMs with demonstrated experience and capability to provide reliable large-scale electrolyzers. Given the first-of-their-kind nature of large-scale green hydrogen projects, quality, safety, and flexibility of electrolyzers are likely to be key issues that OEMs may have to face.</p>
<p>Developers are likely to look for top-tier OEMs that are able to guarantee operational performance of electrolyzers. Therefore, although the total announced electrolyzer manufacturing capacity might be enough to meet targets for installed electrolyzer capacity, only top-tier OEMs with secured backlogs might be able to move ahead with their manufacturing facilities, while second-tier OEMs compete for a more uncertain demand. This barrier could be overcome by supporting pilot projects to generate knowledge on technology scale-up, allowing for faster-time-to-market of technological breakthroughs. Such support could come from both private and public institutions.</p>
<p>Another opportunity for Spain would be to incentivize local green hydrogen supply chains, including efforts to attract major international manufacturers with expansion plans. Some potential strategies to attract these electrolyzer manufacturers could involve introducing economic incentives, reducing permitting burdens, developing skilled local talent, and ensuring the availability of supply chains for electrolyzers, as well as engineering, procurement, and construction companies (EPCs) with which to partner. Spain is already one of the preferred choices for some electrolyzer manufacturers, such as Cummins, a global hydrogen player that is building an electrolyzer manufacturing facility in Guadalajara, Spain, expected to come operational in 2024.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e0241c70-991c-40a3-9386-fbb4931b02da"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">33</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e0241c70-991c-40a3-9386-fbb4931b02da" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">El Digital Castilla-la Mancha, “The Cummins gigafactory in Guadalajara passes the last procedure before its start-up,” El Español, December 28, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Another example is the Chinese Hygreen Energy, one of the world’s leading electrolyzer manufacturers, which has recently announced their plans to build a new electrolyzer manufacturing plant in Spain with initial capacity for 1 GW (with plans to expand to up to 5 GW of electrolyzer manufacturing capacity in the future).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="09014ceb-205a-455b-b32b-4531e78e0a93"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">34</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="09014ceb-205a-455b-b32b-4531e78e0a93" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Who is Hygreen Energy? The Chinese giant of electrolyzers for green hydrogen with a strong Spanish accent,” el Economista, August 28, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>However, manufacturers are also choosing competing regions for their new facilities, thanks to the incentives those regions offer. For instance, Cummins expanded its Belgium manufacturing facility to 1 GW, following European (Hy2Tech) and regional (Flanders Innovation and Entrepreneurship Agency) financial support.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4c3ff90b-66f4-4d83-ba01-57cd4492c90a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">35</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4c3ff90b-66f4-4d83-ba01-57cd4492c90a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Cummins scaling Belgium electrolyzer manufacturing capacity to 1 gigawatt through IPCEI support,” Cummins, September 8, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> On the other hand, Nel, one of the European Union’s largest electrolyzer manufacturers, announced a $400 million investment in a new electrolyzer gigafactory in Michigan, United States, with the direct federal and state incentives amounting to $150 million as a crucial factor in this decision.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b8815c6d-f2f0-4261-b282-9a74e310124b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">36</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b8815c6d-f2f0-4261-b282-9a74e310124b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Holly Martin, “Electrolyser maker Nel stacks up nearly $170m in subsidies for proposed Michigan gigafactory,” Hydrogen Insight, April 5, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span> The United States has attracted several top-tier electrolyzer manufacturers by awarding a total of $335 million of investment tax credits for new hydrogen-equipment manufacturing facilities under the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA 48C).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d3a8b78b-96c9-430d-b5cf-524048db5cd2"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">37</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d3a8b78b-96c9-430d-b5cf-524048db5cd2" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Leigh Collins, “US awards about $335m of investment tax credits for new hydrogen-equipment manufacturing facilities,” Hydrogen Insight, April 19, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Beyond electrolyzer manufacturing, Spain could aim to develop certain components internally, including electrical equipment, water treatment and gas management systems, and engineering services to build new green hydrogen production plants.</p>
<p><strong>Feedstock availability (water and renewable energy):</strong> Scarcity of and competition for water resources is a concern in the industry. In Spain, more than 40 percent of announced green hydrogen projects are likely to be located in highly water-stressed areas.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="91090ea5-8b24-4778-92fb-76cfc37d7a44"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">38</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="91090ea5-8b24-4778-92fb-76cfc37d7a44" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Water for hydrogen production</em>, International Renewable Energy Agency and Bluerisk, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Additionally, the configuration of RES (solar, wind, and, potentially, batteries) required to achieve high utilization of electrolyzers could increase the cost of electricity.</p>
<p>These risks could be offset by increasing the efficiency of electrolyzers and cooling processes. This can reduce the overall water withdrawal per kilogram of hydrogen produced. In coastal areas, desalination can also be a cost-effective option (with an estimated price impact of €0.02 to €0.05 per kilogram of hydrogen) to reduce water consumption, but environmental effects of thermal pollution and brine management should be carefully studied before this solution is implemented.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="40fdcf0c-6082-49a1-b5d6-04b3eb5b8f80"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">39</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="40fdcf0c-6082-49a1-b5d6-04b3eb5b8f80" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Water for hydrogen production</em>, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>3. Navigating EU and Spanish regulation on green hydrogen</h3>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>EU regulations on green hydrogen</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><h2>1. EU Delegated Acts for RFNBOs</h2>
<p>In 2023, the European Union approved the First and Second EU Delegated Acts (DA) defining the taxonomy and minimum requirements for green hydrogen and RFNBO production certification, highlighting the following criteria:</p>
<h3>First EU DA</h3>
<p><strong>Additionality:</strong> For facilities entering operation after 2028, RES installation must come into operation not earlier than 36 months before the green hydrogen production facility and cannot have received operating or investment public aid.</p>
<p><strong>Temporal correlation:</strong> The time period between renewable power generation and hydrogen production must be no longer than one month before 2030, and one hour afterwards. Charge and storage assets must also comply with temporal correlation.</p>
<p><strong>Geographical correlation:</strong> The RES and electrolyzer must be in the same bidding zone (Spain is a single bidding zone).</p>
<h3>Second EU DA</h3>
<p><strong>Emissions savings:</strong> Green hydrogen-based synthetic fuels will need to achieve minimum CO<sub>2</sub> emissions savings of 70 percent versus a conventional fuel alternative for it to be considered an RFNBO.</p>
<p>There are other alternatives to ease DA requirements based on percentage of RES in the grid, the level of curtailment, and low power prices. Since electricity plays a key role in the production of green hydrogen (over 50 percent of the cost), these requirements have material impact on the LCOH. </p>
<h2>2. EU RFNBO quotas and regulatory demand</h2>
<p>On the other hand, RFNBO quotas in the updated RED, FuelEU, and ReFuelEU initiatives lay out a minimum regulatory demand for green hydrogen in sectors that already use hydrogen (such as refining and chemicals), as well as in new uses (such as transportation).</p>
<p><strong>RED III</strong> establishes the need for 42 percent of hydrogen consumed in industry to be green by 2030, resulting in a regulatory demand in refining of around 0.05 Mtpa and of 0.12 to 0.16 Mtpa for chemicals in Spain by 2030.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="5580297d-a1ba-49f5-8355-e14f253584ad"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="5580297d-a1ba-49f5-8355-e14f253584ad" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Assuming 80 percent of all hydrogen in refining is used for conventional transport fuels and the other 20 percent for industrial products. Also assumes that 25 percent of all hydrogen used is obtained as a by-product of crude cracking (not considered for the quotas). Based on our analysis and considering the multipliers specified in RED III for RFNBOs in maritime and aviation, no further RFNBOs would be needed in our “Refining” or “Road” category.</span></span></span></a></span> RED III also imposes quotas on the total energy used in the transport sector of 5.5 percent advanced biofuels and RFNBO, with 1.0 percent subquota of RFNBO, and 29.0 percent RES (or, alternatively, a 14.5 percent greenhouse gas [GHG] reduction). Assuming that RFNBOs in maritime and aviation can be used to cover RFNBO quotas in transport from RED III, there would not be further regulatory demand for RFNBOs in refining or road transport to cover the 1 percent subquota. However, our analysis shows that using green hydrogen for conventional fuel refining in Spain is a cost-competitive lever to contribute to transport quotas in RED III beyond the 1 percent RFNBO. This could lead to a demand of 0.20 to 0.25 Mtpa of green hydrogen for refining incentivized by regulation.</p>
<p><strong>FuelEU</strong> establishes a 1 percent RFNBO quota for energy consumed in the maritime sector by 2031. If this is not met, then a 2 percent quota would apply from 2034 on. However, RED III also adds a maritime-specific RFNBO quota of 1.2 percent over fuel supplied by 2030, which would lead to a regulatory demand of 0.03 to 0.05 Mtpa of green hydrogen for maritime in Spain by 2030. FuelEU quotas will be applicable to vessel operators, while RED III applies to fuel suppliers (pending transposition by member states).</p>
<p><strong>ReFuelEU</strong> establishes a 1.2 percent RFNBO quota for energy consumed in aviation by 2030, leading to a regulatory demand of 0.05 to 0.07 Mtpa of green hydrogen for aviation in Spain by 2030. This quota will be applicable to aviation fuel distributors. To help achieve the most cost-competitive way to achieve these targets, the European Union is finalizing the details of a “flexibility mechanism” that will allow these blending obligations for each fuel provider to be averaged across EU airports until 2035. A book-and-claim system is also under discussion to allow for a credit system to be used to reach RFNBO quotas (similar to guarantees of origin for renewable power). Additionally, to prevent tankering practices, airlines will be obliged to refuel at least 90 percent of their yearly required aviation fuel within the European Union.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>There are numerous EU and Spanish regulations that could impact the cost-efficiency of green hydrogen, as well as demand and willingness to pay (see sidebar “EU regulations on green hydrogen”).</p>
<p>To ensure that the regulatory demand is met, penalties for noncompliance with the RFNBO quotas will be put in place. We conducted a theoretical exercise to estimate the potential impact of these penalties on the willingness-to-pay (WTP) by calculating the decarbonization potential of green hydrogen and its derivatives for each application assuming a potential penalty of €400 per ton of CO<sub>2</sub> “not saved” (Exhibit 4).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="87f36108-a905-4704-8b00-ad223bca7c14"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">40</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="87f36108-a905-4704-8b00-ad223bca7c14" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">This level of penalty is similar to that found in the transposition of RED II for biofuel targets in some EU countries. However, it is important to note that the real penalties will be defined by the European Union and member states. For RED III, member states will define their own penalties when transposing the directive; for FuelEU a unified penalty will be defined by the European Union, pending on setting a price for sustainable maritime fuel; and for ReFuelEU, member states will define the penalties, starting from a minimum penalty set by the European Union and pending on setting a price for synthetic kerosene.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/the%20iberian%20green%20industrial%20opportunity%20green%20hydrogen/svgz-spain-and-portugal-chapter3_ex4-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The potential impact of penalties on the willingness to pay was analyzed." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/the%20iberian%20green%20industrial%20opportunity%20green%20hydrogen/svgz-spain-and-portugal-chapter3_ex4-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>For refining, the impact on WTP of this theoretical penalty could be €3.3 to €3.7 per kilogram of green hydrogen not fulfilled. It would have a similar impact on chemicals. In maritime, the impact would be €3.2 to €2.8 per kilogram of green hydrogen not met (estimate based on the carbon intensity of low-sulfur, heavy fuel oil compared to e-methanol), while aviation could see an impact of €1.8 to €2.2 per kilogram of green hydrogen (conventional kerosene compared to synthetic kerosene).</p>
<h4>Challenges and unlocks</h4>
<p><strong>Delegated Act requirements:</strong> Temporal matching, when required on an hourly basis after 2030, would be the main constraint to developers, as it constrains the use of PPAs and guarantees of origin. Also, additionality of RES will still be required for projects starting after 2028 if Spain’s grid emissions do not fall below 18g CO<sub>2</sub> per megajoule (MJ). While additionality is still in place, projects will face RES permitting timelines of between two and six years and will not be eligible for public funding. In addition, producers would be required to prove a 70 percent reduction in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions intensity of the hydrogen and synthetic fuels produced compared to conventional fuels to be considered RFNBO.</p>
<p>Restrictions on using grid electricity and the high intermittency of RES could lead to an irregular output of green hydrogen. This enters into conflict with the output requirements for hydrogen derivative production like ammonia, methanol, e-fuel, and green steel production. Firmness constraints could also lead to significant RES oversizing and storage needs.</p>
<p>To overcome these barriers, temporal correlation requirements could be eased by fostering and investing in large-scale storage. Requirements could also be standardized to avoid cross-border recognition challenges within the European Union and with third country trade partners.</p>
<p>Additionally, visibility on timelines to reach green grid conditions could be provided. If Spain’s grid emissions fall under 18g CO<sub>2</sub> per MJ (compared to around 35g CO<sub>2</sub> per MJ in 2023), this would allow producers to avoid the additionality requirement.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f363085f-6d6e-412b-861f-118eead01834"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">41</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f363085f-6d6e-412b-861f-118eead01834" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">For further information, see Red Eléctrica’s website, iee.es/es.</span></span></span></a></span> According to a draft PNIEC review to be approved in 2024, the Spanish grid aspires to reach emissions of around 12g CO<sub>2</sub> per MJ in 2025 and around 8g CO<sub>2</sub> per MJ in 2030.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="fc4ac76f-77f3-4772-8574-c6c7604b780a"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">42</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="fc4ac76f-77f3-4772-8574-c6c7604b780a" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Draft update of the national integrated energy and climate plan 2023–2030,” Spanish Ministry for the Ecological Transition and the Demographic Challenge, June 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> In line with this, some European developers are already adjusting their PPA lengths to switch to regular grid connection as soon as decarbonization thresholds are expected to be reached. Also, a proportion of annual RES generation over 90 percent in the bidding zone would allow for direct connection to the grid without temporal correlation or additionality requirements.</p>
<p><strong>RFNBO quotas and penalties:</strong> Spain has not yet defined quotas and penalties in line with the latest regulation (including RED III and ReFuelEU), with final transposition expected to be completed by 2025–26. By that time, most of the green hydrogen projects should have passed FID to meet PNIEC’s electrolyzer capacity target by 2030. Additionally, there are significant differences in penalties established in the past across different EU countries (such as for RED II), generating a risk of “carbon leakage” to countries with lower or no penalties. There is also uncertainty around how the RFNBO certification process will work.</p>
<p>To address these barriers, an RFNBO credit market could be created to allow companies to trade credits to meet their obligations, similar to how the European Union’s emissions trading system (ETS) works today but focused on RFNBOs. Unifying penalties for noncompliance with RFNBO targets across countries could be key to restrict “carbon leakage.” Finally, Spain could also incentivize players to use green hydrogen to decarbonize by covering additional costs incurred by switching technologies. This could be done, for example, with mechanisms such as contracts for difference (CfD) or carbon contracts for difference (CCfD).</p>
<h3>4. Financing first-of-their-kind green hydrogen projects and making them bankable</h3>
<p>Achieving Spain’s aspiration for green hydrogen production would require large capital deployment, around €20,000 million (without considering RES) for the target of 11 GW of installed electrolyzer capacity, according to our analysis.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6eaee0ce-432f-4bb6-bc85-c5ed6c0874ff"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">43</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6eaee0ce-432f-4bb6-bc85-c5ed6c0874ff" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Assuming average capex of €1,750 per MW of electrolyzers installed.</span></span></span></a></span> This, together with the high-risk profile derived from the first-of-their-kind nature of announced projects, make the development of large-scale green hydrogen production plants a challenge.</p>
<p>Some of the necessary capex could be covered by public incentives schemes such as the Spanish PERTE-EHRA incentives or by part of the more than €500,000 million in EU incentives available for the energy transition. However, an estimated 70 to 90 percent of the total capex would have to come from the private sector. Large developers could be able to fund smaller projects (tens of megawatts) using their own equity and corporate debt. Our analysis shows that, for larger projects (hundreds of megawatts and above), project finance-like structures could be used, with 60 to 75 percent of the investments covered by debt investors (such as private banks, multilaterals, and export credit agencies) requesting additional guarantees, with the remainder financed through sponsors’ equity (such as developers and infrastructure funds).</p>
<p>However, the window of opportunity is narrowing. Spain may need to act fast to attract these investments and seize the opportunity to become a leader in green hydrogen.</p>
<h4>Challenges and unlocks</h4>
<p><strong>Public incentives:</strong> Transparency and effectiveness of hydrogen incentive mechanisms are important to maximize their utility. Only around 15 percent of Spain’s PERTE-EHRA incentives had been allocated (not yet disbursed) by the end of 2023, delaying access to these funds. Surveyed stakeholders report that the high level of uncertainty of hydrogen tenders, compared to simple and tradable production tax credits considered in the US IRA, significantly delays final investment decisions, especially as tender results have also been delayed. In addition, complex administrative processes, incompatibility of subsidies, and funds being diluted by numerous projects with various levels of feasibility might limit the efficiency of funding allocation.</p>
<p>To overcome this barrier, public support could be streamlined by standardizing application processes. Different incentives could be clearly mapped with transparent and shorter deadlines while allowing companies to submit several applications in parallel or through a “one-stop shop” application process. For example, Belgium and France combine procedures of several permitting processes into “single permits.”<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="217294bd-f2ef-4236-bb9d-8c8033e57167"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">44</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="217294bd-f2ef-4236-bb9d-8c8033e57167" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Guidance to member states on good practices to accelerate permitting processes,” European Commission, Directorate-General for Energy, May 18, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span> On top of this, penalties could be defined for projects accepting public funding and not delivering the announced results in order to avoid speculative accumulation of incentives.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>EU Hydrogen Bank</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>In April 2024, the European Union launched its pilot auction to distribute the production incentives from the European Hydrogen Bank. The auction received 132 bids from 17 countries, with more than a third of the bids coming from projects in Spain. The auction allocated €720 million to seven projects, three from Spain, two from Portugal, one from Norway, and one from Finland, with relatively low bidding prices (awardees bid €0.37 to €0.48 per kilogram of hydrogen) compared to the ceiling price of €4.5 per kilogram or to the average declared LCOH (€5.8 per kilogram for Spain, the third lowest behind only Sweden and Greece, which only had two bids each).</p>
<p>Several insights emerged from the auction:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Bidders announced a median expected time before entry into operation of less than three years from grant agreement signature.</li>
    <li>Proton exchange membrane (PEM) technology was the most common electrolyzer technology among bidders, closely followed by alkaline technology (although PEM projects reported a higher average LCOH).</li>
    <li>Average expected offtake prices ranged from €5.67 per kilogram in industry to €8.34 per kilogram in mobility, with over half of the bidders expecting industrial offtakers. Reported industrial end uses included methanol, fertilizer, refining, injection in pipeline, steel, chemicals, glass, or power generation, while mobility subsectors included hydrogen refueling stations, logistics, maritime, heavy-duty trucking, bus transport, synthetic methane, and aviation.</li>
    <li>Projects expected a variety of offtake price and hedging structures. Most of the bidders reported fixed or mixed (variable and fixed) price structures, while hedging structures were more diverse. The most common structures were “indexed to inflation” and “pass through (linked to energy price).”</li>
    <li>The European Union allows for member states to voluntarily expand this auction in their own territory through a mechanism known as auction-as-a-service in which member states can support projects that did not win the EU-level auction. For instance, Germany allocated €350 million for a national auction that, based on European Hydrogen Bank results, would cover three to four projects that had not been awarded funding in the European-wide auction. Other EU countries, such as Denmark, have launched their own parallel auction with similar results in terms of low bidding prices.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>There are two types of support mechanisms: investment incentives, including most of the incentives currently available in the European Union, and production incentive, such as tax credits for hydrogen production or competitive bidding schemes for production grants (see sidebar “EU Hydrogen Bank”). Regulators should explore the efficiency of the different incentive structures to determine which schemes should be prioritized. Some EU countries, such as Germany, are choosing auction-as-a-service schemes as the preferred option to allocate public incentives.</p>
<p>Optimization can also be achieved by finding the right balance between allocating large incentives to a smaller number of projects or more modest incentives to many initiatives, with the former being the preferred option among the Iberian Industry and Energy Transition Initiative members. Other criteria can be followed to further optimize the distribution of incentives, for example, prioritizing projects with offtake agreements or prioritizing those with the highest potential to reduce emissions on end-use applications.</p>
<p><strong>Private funding:</strong> The first-of-their-kind nature of large-scale green hydrogen projects means they can require substantial capex investments with risk profiles similar to those of early-stage technologies. Developers can apply derisking levers to better attract debt and equity providers by managing the main risks, including financial and technical risks.</p>
<p>Financial risks include low cash flow predictability due to the emerging nature of the green hydrogen market or the lack of long-term offtakers (less than 10 percent of the announced projects in Spain publicly announced a signed offtake agreement as of the second quarter of 2024). Merchant exposure restrictions by equity and debt investors may vary for different end products (ammonia has a global merchant market, while the green hydrogen market is still immature). Additionally, smaller entities may struggle to prove creditworthiness due to limited resources and unclear track record, requiring partnerships with experienced EPCs and operations and maintenance companies.</p>
<p>Technical risks include a lack of experienced EPC players and issues when scaling electrolyzer technology. There is a high level of uncertainty regarding long-term maintenance and operational costs as well as difficulties in securing competitive long-term power supply agreements. Debt equity investors usually require full visibility on power prices in the long-term through solid PPAs, regardless of whether the project is bundled with RES or not, as well as clear contractual clauses defining the accountability of the different stakeholders along the complex hydrogen value chain.</p>
<p>A potential lever to attract private funding is easing capital requirements through public financial institutions and bank pooling. Multilateral banks and export credit agencies could offer “soft loans” with favorable repayment conditions as well as guarantees that improve the financial reliability of these projects. This was demonstrated by Euler Hermes, the European Investment Bank, and the Swedish National Debt Office providing debt, cover, and guarantee for H2 Green Steel.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ebb08632-e2da-4994-9954-3f57872cb8d8"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">45</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ebb08632-e2da-4994-9954-3f57872cb8d8" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“H2 Green Steel raises more than €4 billion in debt financing for the world’s first large-scale green steel plant,” H2 Green Steel, January 22, 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h3>5. Deploying the infrastructure to develop green hydrogen production, transport, and storage</h3>
<p>The green hydrogen ecosystem in Spain includes the infrastructure to generate and transport the electricity required to produce hydrogen, as well as hydrogen transport and storage systems to connect green hydrogen production initiatives with national and international offtakers via pipelines, shipping, and road transport.</p>
<p>The expansion of green hydrogen production would require the optimization of grid infrastructure to ensure sufficient access capacity for demand to connect electrolyzers and for generation to connect RES to the grid. Additionally, streamlining the permitting process for renewable power generation development would be important to ensure that the announced green hydrogen plants can be operational by 2030. Currently, the average permitting timeline for RES in Spain ranges from two to six years. This would mean that nearly 20 GW of additional RES would have to launch construction by 2027 to 2028 to meet PNIEC’s target of 11 GW electrolyzer capacity by 2030.</p>
<p>There are four main options for transporting hydrogen, depending on distance, terrain, carrier, and end use: pipelines, ships, trucks, and trains. However, the transport of hydrogen over long distances without optimized infrastructure adds sizable costs to hydrogen end products. Therefore, in the short term (before 2030), while adequate transport infrastructure is not yet deployed, production plants for green hydrogen and derivatives would be most efficient if they were co-located to reduce the associated logistics costs.</p>
<p>Within this context, trucks, despite being comparatively more expensive (costs under €1 per kilogram of hydrogen for distances under 100 kilometers), could present an attractive option to absorb low and fluctuating demand in the early stages of the hydrogen economy. In the longer term, national and international pipeline networks and export terminals could gain relevance once exports of green hydrogen and derivatives become more mature. Pipelines will be the most cost-efficient option for both short- and mid-range distribution (cost of less than €0.1 to €2.6 per kilogram for distances between 100 kilometers and 5,000 kilometers), assuming high capacity utilization, leaving shipping as the preferred option for long-range and intercontinental trade (cost of €2.2 to €3.1 per kilogram depending on selected carrier, including conversion costs).<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bf04ddb8-7774-495e-9492-cd5cbbe42aff"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">46</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bf04ddb8-7774-495e-9492-cd5cbbe42aff" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">H2 and carriers transport cost estimations obtained from <em>European Hydrogen Backbone 2023</em> report, European Hydrogen Backbone, 2024; and <em>Global hydrogen review 2023</em>, IEA, September 22, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Another alternative would be to use cargo trains, to transport hydrogen derivatives from production source to demand or export points (less expensive than trucks but more costly than pipelines or inland vessels).</p>
<p>Once economies of scale and production technology maturity are reached, a hydrogen transportation ecosystem can help connect hydrogen production and demand hubs across regions. The European Hydrogen Backbone, a transmission system operator (TSO)-led nonbinding initiative, already envisions a Pan-European hydrogen pipeline network, including a Spanish National Backbone with an inner mesh and connections with France and Portugal, aiming to turn Spain into a major green hydrogen supplier in Europe (Exhibit 5).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/the%20iberian%20green%20industrial%20opportunity%20green%20hydrogen/svgz-spain-and-portugal-chapter3_ex5-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Spanish TSO is planning to deploy the first phase of the Spanish Hydrogen Backbone by 2030, including the connection to France." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/electric%20power%20and%20natural%20gas/our%20insights/the%20iberian%20green%20industrial%20opportunity%20green%20hydrogen/svgz-spain-and-portugal-chapter3_ex5-v9.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>Although some sections such as the BarMar connection have started their preliminary engineering studies, this grid section is not likely to be deployed by the announced timelines and other international connections could be subject to additional delays, as observed in other cross-border infrastructures. However, if the grid is deployed at scale in the future, this would give a clear competitive advantage to EU green hydrogen producers over overseas ones that would need to convert the hydrogen into a shipping carrier and then reconvert it back to hydrogen, increasing landed cost.</p>
<p>Hydrogen storage provides the output firmness required by green hydrogen offtakers, partially solving the electrolyzer utilization constraints that stem from the inherent intermittency of RES. Hydrogen storage is a versatile technology, but it is currently in the early stages of its development. In the short term, artificial tanks (storing compressed or liquid hydrogen) may be more suitable due to higher technology maturity and flexibility to adapt to small-scale storage. In the long run, geological storage has the potential to be the most competitive option for large-scale, long-term storage to bridge major seasonal changes in production and demand.</p>
<h4>Challenges and unlocks</h4>
<p><strong>Power grid infrastructure access for hydrogen production:</strong> A lengthy and difficult permitting process in Spain may be delaying target commercial operation dates (COD) for green hydrogen production plants. Furthermore, the accommodation of 11 GW of electrolyzer capacity, as well as over 20 GW of dedicated RES generation for green hydrogen production by 2030, would require significant upgrades to the transmission grid, substations, and lines. Finally, grid fees in Spain could represent a substantial portion (15 to 25 percent)<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3fa5233c-6f0e-468a-b3da-e52f9bf43b64"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">47</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3fa5233c-6f0e-468a-b3da-e52f9bf43b64" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Assuming an average electricity price of around €50.0 per MWh and a grid fee for electro intensives of €11.4 per MWh.</span></span></span></a></span> of final electricity cost, impacting the LCOH directly.</p>
<p>Several interventions could be considered. First, the RES permitting process could be sped up by transposing the EU Renewable Energy Act to national regulation, incorporating the maximum of two years of permitting processes for new RES projects.<strong> </strong>Second, the grid access process could be facilitated by creating a one-stop shop for all permitting-related requests. For example, in the United States, FAST-41 oversees projects with a value of more than $200 million, tracking timetables and providing transparency, including completion dates for all federal authorizations and environmental reviews.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="45055986-5aa5-4717-a389-08927591680d"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">48</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="45055986-5aa5-4717-a389-08927591680d" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Fast-41,” United States Office of Electricity, accessed August 2024.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Third, grid access capacity could be ensured by planning and executing the required investments. According to our analysis, grid expansion is a critical enabler with relatively low investment requirements compared to the €20,000 million of total capex needed for electrolyzer production capacity to meet Spain’s 2030 target.</p>
<p>To accommodate 11 GW of electrolyzer capacity for green hydrogen projects, the Spanish grid will require further upgrades in the new 2025–30 plan that the national grid TSO is developing (as of April 2024). This was already done in the previous 2021–26 plan review with, for example, Repsol’s green hydrogen project in Tarragona and the new Francolí substation. Planned investments in upgrading or expanding the transmission grid would need to be coordinated with the development of the most viable green hydrogen projects through an objective categorization based on development phase, committed offtakers, and public support, among other criteria. Agile planning adjustments should be facilitated to quickly identify future green hydrogen hubs and reassess investment needs, while financial guarantees could help avoid speculative attributions of capacity.</p>
<p>Fourth, stakeholders could explore alternatives to reduce the impact of power costs. For example, granting exemptions for certain grid fees for energy-intensive industries. These policies would need to consider the risk of incompatibility with other incentives and the impact on other grid fee payers.</p>
<p><strong>Hydrogen transport infrastructure:</strong> Hydrogen transmission pipelines could kickstart a network of connected green hydrogen producers and offtakers maintaining cost-competitiveness at a national and continental scale. However, demand uncertainty and the large investments required, along with operational risks, could cast doubt on the cost-effectiveness of deploying national and international hydrogen pipeline infrastructure. In addition, the long-distance shipping of green hydrogen is yet to be proven at scale, with no carrier emerging as a clear frontrunner (ammonia is the most frequently announced today). Immature reconversion technologies and the lack of existing port infrastructure compound the difficulty of establishing intercontinental trade routes by 2030. In parallel, the development of the hydrogen ecosystem would have to go hand in hand with the definition of safety protocols, especially for new use cases (both end products like ammonia and infrastructure).</p>
<p>To overcome this barrier, stakeholders could explore public–private partnerships to establish international hydrogen supply chains, such as through international import-export agreements that ensure enough demand to justify investments in port infrastructure. For example, ACE Terminal and Cepsa signed an agreement to export green ammonia from southern Spain to a new import terminal in Rotterdam.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="d8227762-7c7a-4ca5-a2b6-363096437896"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">49</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="d8227762-7c7a-4ca5-a2b6-363096437896" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Cepsa and ACE Terminal join forces to create green hydrogen supply chain from Spain to the Netherlands,” Cepsa, February 20, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> Developing and maturing ammonia (or other hydrogen carriers) cracking technologies and capabilities in import terminals would also be key to unlocking international trade. In addition, TSOs could be incentivized to invest in infrastructure build-out with compensation mechanisms if utilizations fall under a minimum threshold, similar to the system used in UK’s Nuclear Regulated Asset Base that ensures a base level of revenues for nuclear generators even when underutilized.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bc537833-2e13-4e19-b9f7-8ec11c4721c7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">50</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bc537833-2e13-4e19-b9f7-8ec11c4721c7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">“Guidance: Nuclear regulated asset base (RAB) model: Statement on procedure and criteria for designation,” Department for Energy Security and Net Zero and Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy, UK Government, April 11, 2022.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>The targeted development of hydrogen infrastructure could be enabled through cost-efficient retrofitting of natural gas pipelines and hydrogen corridors prioritization, avoiding extensive oversizing in the short term, which would hinder the economic viability of the system. In Belgium, Fluxys is building a dual-purpose pipeline, ready to switch from natural gas to hydrogen transport when needed.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="025fcf38-b240-4f48-8a5f-a023e78f4274"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">51</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="025fcf38-b240-4f48-8a5f-a023e78f4274" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Sarah Simper, “Fluxys builds new natural gas and hydrogen pipeline,” World Pipelines, June 8, 2023.</span></span></span></a></span> The development of announced pipeline projects would have to be in line with the maturity of the green hydrogen production ecosystem and the readiness of players to import or export hydrogen as a molecule (not as a derivative). This could further attract green hydrogen producers to Spain to export hydrogen toward their offtaking facilities in Central Europe.</p>
<p>In addition, stakeholders could invest in research to overcome technological barriers that deter the use of hydrogen carriers as transportation vectors. This could align different regions and countries on a single carrier regulation and harmonize their infrastructure needs.</p>
<hr>
<p>Spain is in a favorable position to become a major green hydrogen producer in the European Union thanks to its natural and technical endowments, which create a unique window of opportunity for the development of a new ecosystem.</p>
<p>However, green hydrogen faces several challenges that would need to be addressed for Spain to realize its ambitions. Private and public stakeholders could act now to embrace the opportunity of turning Spain into a leading EU green hydrogen hub—generating sustained growth in the country while achieving the decarbonization of hard-to-abate sectors.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong>André Anacleto</strong> is a partner in McKinsey’s Lisbon office, where <strong><a href="/our-people/maria-joao-ribeirinho">Maria João Ribeirinho</a></strong> is a senior partner; <strong><a href="/our-people/bernd-heid">Bernd Heid</a></strong> is a senior partner in the New York office, where <strong>Maurits Waardenburg</strong> is a partner; <strong><a href="/our-people/david-gonzalez">David González</a></strong> is a senior partner in the Madrid office, where <strong>Javier Ferrer García</strong> is a partner, and <strong>Ignacio Martínez</strong>, <strong>Segismundo García</strong>, and <strong>Ugaitz Bartolomé</strong> are consultants.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Denitsa Georgieva, José Pimenta da Gama, Joseba Eceiza, Juan Antonio Bahillo, Tomás Calleja, and Xavier Riba for their contributions to this article.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-screen-only"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-5 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-9"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">Explore a career with us</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--align-center___ar3mu_990311c"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/careers/search-jobs" class="mdc-c-button___U4iY2_990311c mdc-c-button--secondary___Boipq_990311c mdc-c-button--size-large___jwpUy_990311c" aria-label="Search Openings"
