current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eToday, more than 99 percent of the hydrogen produced globally is grey (obtained from natural gas via steam methane reforming [SMR]) or black or brown (produced from coal), all of which produce CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e as a by-product.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe renewable alternative to grey hydrogen is green (or renewable, based on EU taxonomy)[[footnote 2]] hydrogen, which is produced from water by electrolysis using renewable energy sources. In 2022, less than 1 percent of hydrogen was produced via electrolysis globally.[[footnote 3]] While there are other low-carbon hydrogen production routes, such as blue hydrogen (produced from fossil fuels but including CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e capture, utilization, or storage) and white hydrogen (from geological origin), these are not yet mature either.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCompared to other decarbonization vectors, green hydrogen can have lower efficiency than electrification in some uses due to the cumulative energy loss in the production process. Other green gases, such as biomethane, currently have a lower trading cost than green hydrogen, with biomethane trading at \u0026euro;80 to \u0026euro;120 per megawatt hour (MWh) compared to \u0026euro;200 to \u0026euro;220 per MWh for green hydrogen and \u0026euro;25 to \u0026euro;30 per MWh for natural gas.[[footnote 4]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, green hydrogen has several characteristics that make it an attractive decarbonization alternative for some sectors. It does not experience the feedstock constraints that can affect biofuel and biogas production. It has a higher energy density than existing batteries and has the capacity to be stored and to discharge large amounts of energy for long durations. It also has the capacity to provide high-temperature heat when burned and has a higher chemical flexibility than other alternatives.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"About green hydrogen"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGlobal hydrogen review 2023\u003c/em\u003e, International Energy Agency, September 2023.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFollowing the RFNBO definition of the First Delegated Act: \"As a principle, liquid and gaseous fuels of nonbiological origin which are produced from electricity are considered renewable only when the electricity is renewable. This renewable electricity may be supplied by an installation that is directly connected to the installation (typically an electrolyzer) that produces renewable liquid and gaseous transport fuels of nonbiological origin, or may come directly from the grid.\"\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGlobal hydrogen review 2023\u003c/em\u003e, September 2023.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDutch TTF natural gas futures, accessed April 10, 2024; EXX HYDRIX index, European Energy Exchange, accessed March 2024; For more on biomethane, see \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/the-iberian-green-industrial-opportunity-biomethane\"\u003eThe Iberian green industrial opportunity: Biomethane\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; McKinsey, August 1, 2024.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"2"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eSpain and Portugal\u0026rsquo;s decarbonization targets to achieve net zero by 2050 will require participation from all sectors and industries. McKinsey set up the Iberian Industry and Energy Transition Initiative to act as a leading think tank and a demand and investment accelerator on the Iberian Peninsula. The main goal of the Initiative is to help Spain and Portugal realize their decarbonization goals while capturing the opportunity to develop new industries and scale existing ones.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe Iberian Industry and Energy Transition Initiative currently comprises more than ten founding members, including leading energy, industrial, and financial organizations. Initiative members attend periodic meetings to discuss key thematic missions around the way forward for energy and industry in Spain and Portugal.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the first quarter of 2024, over 20 roundtables were held to discuss the topics of electrification and renewables, as well as renewable molecules (including green hydrogen, sustainable fuels, and biomethane). The insights from these roundtables helped to inform this article series, which focuses on Spain, though many of the insights can be applied to Portugal as well. A variety of stakeholders will be involved in the effort; public-private collaboration will be essential to materialize the Initiative\u0026rsquo;s vision.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The Iberian Industry and Energy Transition Initiative"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"3"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eChanges in different variables, including electrolyzer efficiency, electricity cost, plant and electrolyzer capex, utilization, and cost of equity, would impact the LCOH to different extents (exhibit).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[exhibit side]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe two variables with the greatest positive impact on the LCOH (reducing the cost) are those with a direct impact on the total cost of electricity (electrolyzer efficiency and electricity cost), which accounts for 50 to 60 percent of the LCOH. Increasing electrolyzer efficiency from current levels of around 65 percent (associated with the more mature alkaline and proton exchange membrane [PEM] technologies) to 80 percent (similar to the levels announced for state-of-the-art solid oxide electrolyzer cells [SOEC]) could reduce the LCOH by up to \u0026euro;0.8 per kilogram (15 to 20 percent of the LCOH). Similarly, changes in electricity cost also have a relatively large impact on the LCOH. Being able to secure PPAs at low prices would be key to producing hydrogen at a competitive cost, and Spain could benefit from its natural endowments in this regard. Additionally, grid access fees also play a critical role in the total electricity cost, with current fees in Spain around \u0026euro;10 to \u0026euro;15 per MWh for industries like green hydrogen production.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother large contribution to reducing the LCOH could come from achieving projected capex reductions once the market matures and engineering, procurement, and construction companies (EPCs) and OEMs gain the necessary experience and economies of scale. A reduction of 25 to 30 percent in capex could reduce the LCOH by \u0026euro;0.5 to \u0026euro;0.6 per kilogram (10 to 15 percent of the LCOH). Electrolyzer utilization can also have a large impact on the LCOH, especially when reducing utilization below 50 percent. However, utilization is directly linked to RES configuration, which would change electricity costs\u003cspan\u003e \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eat the same time and in the opposite direction. Last, although financial cost can impact the LCOH, the contribution of changes in cost of equity would have limited impact compared to other variables considering a project finance structure with a 75 percent leverage ratio. The impact of the cost of equity could be higher for smaller projects where sponsors provide most capital as equity.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"LCOH sensitivity analysis"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"4"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eSome green hydrogen producers could seek additional revenue streams. Although these will not be available for all of them, the additional revenue streams could help some projects improve their economic viability. These could include:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOptimal direct RES and grid connection mix:\u003c/strong\u003e One option is to leverage new RES in combination with connection to the grid. By doing this, hydrogen producers could sell green hydrogen according to the percentage of renewable electricity used (both from direct RES and grid with PPA) and sell the rest as low-carbon or grey hydrogen (depending on the emission intensity of the electricity used from the grid). In fact, several Spanish projects are currently considering this strategy for hydrogen derivatives (for example, producing RFNBO, low carbon, and \u0026ldquo;grey electrolytic\u0026rdquo; ammonia under the same facility connected to the grid).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGrid balancing compensation mechanisms:\u003c/strong\u003e Another option would be to incorporate the electrolyzers into the \u0026ldquo;active response to demand service,\u0026rdquo; which allows the transmission system operator (TSO) to order mandatory stops of operations to balance the grid. In exchange, green hydrogen producers would receive a fixed fee for making themselves available for the service, and extra variable fees for those hours they are asked to stop. This mechanism could constitute an extra revenue source for those few projects that manage to secure some capacity in the bidding process.[[footnote 1]] Due to higher RES penetration increasing intermittency of the power grid, an increased necessity for grid demand adjustment capacity is expected in the coming years. However, it is important to note that as the number of bidders for this mechanism increases, prices for these services would go down, reducing the potential revenue.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eCommercialization of by-product oxygen:\u003c/strong\u003e Another possibility some players have explored, such as Everfuel\u0026rsquo;s facility in Denmark, is to sell the oxygen produced during electrolysis (around eight kilograms of oxygen are produced for every kilogram of hydrogen) to be used for oxy-fuel combustions or as feedstock in industry.[[footnote 2]] The existing oxygen market is small and balanced, therefore the introduction of large quantities of by-product oxygen could cause an oversupply shock and a sudden price decrease, making this revenue stream less appealing. However, new uses of oxygen might become relevant to increase efficiency of metals and cement furnaces by displacing nitrogen during combustion in a process known as oxy-fuel combustion, increasing the demand for this gas. Other uses include wastewater treatment and pulp and paper production, among others.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Other potential revenue streams"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eFor the 2023 auction of the Spanish grid, a total capacity of 497 MW was awarded to be available for 2,714 hours. The average fixed price paid was \u0026euro;70 per MW and per available hour. This year, the service was only used for three hours, paying an additional variable price of \u0026euro;133 per MW and stopped hour. For the 2024 auction, a total capacity of 609 MW was awarded to be available for 5,745 hours. The average fixed price paid was \u0026euro;41 per MW and per available hour.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eLeih Collins, \u0026ldquo;Additional revenue stream\u0026mdash;Byproduct oxygen from 300MW green hydrogen project sold in long-term deal,\u0026rdquo; Hydrogen Insight, January 3, 2023.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"5"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003ch2\u003e1. EU Delegated Acts for RFNBOs\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn 2023, the European Union approved the First and Second EU Delegated Acts (DA) defining the taxonomy and minimum requirements for green hydrogen and RFNBO production certification, highlighting the following criteria:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFirst EU DA\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAdditionality:\u003c/strong\u003e For facilities entering operation after 2028, RES installation must come into operation not earlier than 36 months before the green hydrogen production facility and cannot have received operating or investment public aid.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eTemporal correlation:\u003c/strong\u003e The time period between renewable power generation and hydrogen production must be no longer than one month before 2030, and one hour afterwards. Charge and storage assets must also comply with temporal correlation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGeographical correlation:\u003c/strong\u003e The RES and electrolyzer must be in the same bidding zone (Spain is a single bidding zone).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eSecond EU DA\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEmissions savings:\u003c/strong\u003e Green hydrogen-based synthetic fuels will need to achieve minimum CO\u003csub\u003e2\u003c/sub\u003e emissions savings of 70 percent versus a conventional fuel alternative for it to be considered an RFNBO.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are other alternatives to ease DA requirements based on percentage of RES in the grid, the level of curtailment, and low power prices. Since electricity plays a key role in the production of green hydrogen (over 50 percent of the cost), these requirements have material impact on the LCOH. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003e2. EU RFNBO quotas and regulatory demand\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn the other hand, RFNBO quotas in the updated RED, FuelEU, and ReFuelEU initiatives lay out a minimum regulatory demand for green hydrogen in sectors that already use hydrogen (such as refining and chemicals), as well as in new uses (such as transportation).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eRED III\u003c/strong\u003e establishes the need for 42 percent of hydrogen consumed in industry to be green by 2030, resulting in a regulatory demand in refining of around 0.05 Mtpa and of 0.12 to 0.16 Mtpa for chemicals in Spain by 2030.[[footnote 1]] RED III also imposes quotas on the total energy used in the transport sector of 5.5 percent advanced biofuels and RFNBO, with 1.0 percent subquota of RFNBO, and 29.0 percent RES (or, alternatively, a 14.5 percent greenhouse gas [GHG] reduction). Assuming that RFNBOs in maritime and aviation can be used to cover RFNBO quotas in transport from RED III, there would not be further regulatory demand for RFNBOs in refining or road transport to cover the 1 percent subquota. However, our analysis shows that using green hydrogen for conventional fuel refining in Spain is a cost-competitive lever to contribute to transport quotas in RED III beyond the 1 percent RFNBO. This could lead to a demand of 0.20 to 0.25 Mtpa of green hydrogen for refining incentivized by regulation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eFuelEU\u003c/strong\u003e establishes a 1 percent RFNBO quota for energy consumed in the maritime sector by 2031. If this is not met, then a 2 percent quota would apply from 2034 on. However, RED III also adds a maritime-specific RFNBO quota of 1.2 percent over fuel supplied by 2030, which would lead to a regulatory demand of 0.03 to 0.05 Mtpa of green hydrogen for maritime in Spain by 2030. FuelEU quotas will be applicable to vessel operators, while RED III applies to fuel suppliers (pending transposition by member states).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eReFuelEU\u003c/strong\u003e establishes a 1.2 percent RFNBO quota for energy consumed in aviation by 2030, leading to a regulatory demand of 0.05 to 0.07 Mtpa of green hydrogen for aviation in Spain by 2030. This quota will be applicable to aviation fuel distributors. To help achieve the most cost-competitive way to achieve these targets, the European Union is finalizing the details of a \u0026ldquo;flexibility mechanism\u0026rdquo; that will allow these blending obligations for each fuel provider to be averaged across EU airports until 2035. A book-and-claim system is also under discussion to allow for a credit system to be used to reach RFNBO quotas (similar to guarantees of origin for renewable power). Additionally, to prevent tankering practices, airlines will be obliged to refuel at least 90 percent of their yearly required aviation fuel within the European Union.\u003c/p\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"EU regulations on green hydrogen"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAssuming 80 percent of all hydrogen in refining is used for conventional transport fuels and the other 20 percent for industrial products. Also assumes that 25 percent of all hydrogen used is obtained as a by-product of crude cracking (not considered for the quotas). Based on our analysis and considering the multipliers specified in RED III for RFNBOs in maritime and aviation, no further RFNBOs would be needed in our \u0026ldquo;Refining\u0026rdquo; or \u0026ldquo;Road\u0026rdquo; category.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ol\u003e"},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"6"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eIn April 2024, the European Union launched its pilot auction to distribute the production incentives from the European Hydrogen Bank. The auction received 132 bids from 17 countries, with more than a third of the bids coming from projects in Spain. The auction allocated \u0026euro;720 million to seven projects, three from Spain, two from Portugal, one from Norway, and one from Finland, with relatively low bidding prices (awardees bid \u0026euro;0.37 to \u0026euro;0.48 per kilogram of hydrogen) compared to the ceiling price of \u0026euro;4.5 per kilogram or to the average declared LCOH (\u0026euro;5.8 per kilogram for Spain, the third lowest behind only Sweden and Greece, which only had two bids each).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSeveral insights emerged from the auction:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eBidders announced a median expected time before entry into operation of less than three years from grant agreement signature.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eProton exchange membrane (PEM) technology was the most common electrolyzer technology among bidders, closely followed by alkaline technology (although PEM projects reported a higher average LCOH).\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAverage expected offtake prices ranged from \u0026euro;5.67 per kilogram in industry to \u0026euro;8.34 per kilogram in mobility, with over half of the bidders expecting industrial offtakers. Reported industrial end uses included methanol, fertilizer, refining, injection in pipeline, steel, chemicals, glass, or power generation, while mobility subsectors included hydrogen refueling stations, logistics, maritime, heavy-duty trucking, bus transport, synthetic methane, and aviation.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eProjects expected a variety of offtake price and hedging structures. Most of the bidders reported fixed or mixed (variable and fixed) price structures, while hedging structures were more diverse. The most common structures were \u0026ldquo;indexed to inflation\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;pass through (linked to energy price).\u0026rdquo;\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eThe European Union allows for member states to voluntarily expand this auction in their own territory through a mechanism known as auction-as-a-service in which member states can support projects that did not win the EU-level auction. For instance, Germany allocated \u0026euro;350 million for a national auction that, based on European Hydrogen Bank results, would cover three to four projects that had not been awarded funding in the European-wide auction. Other EU countries, such as Denmark, have launched their own parallel auction with similar results in terms of low bidding prices.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"EU Hydrogen Bank"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAssuming 80 percent of all hydrogen in refining is used for conventional transport fuels and the other 20 percent for industrial products. Also assumes that 25 percent of all hydrogen used is obtained as a by-product of crude cracking (not considered for the quotas).
